[Helicopter Cops and Robber game (the jump-searching version)]
For X âŠ† V(G), an X-flap is the vertex set of a connected component of G-X.
Two subsets X,Y âŠ† V(G) touch if N(X) âˆ© Y â‰ âˆ….
A position is a pair (X,R), where XâŠ† V(G) and R is an X-flap.
(X is the set of vertices currently occupied by the cops and R tells us where the robber is
â€” since she can run arbitrarily fast, all that matters is which component of G-X contains her.)
At the start, the cops choose a subset X_0, and the robber chooses an X_0-flap R_0.
Note that if there are k cops in the game, then |X_0| â‰¤ k.
At the start of round i, we have some position (X_i-1,R_i-1).
The cops choose a new set X_iâŠ† V(G) with |X_i| â‰¤ k (and no other restriction), and announce it.
Then the robber, knowing X_i, chooses an X_i-flap R_i which touches R_i-1.
If this is not possible then the cops have won.
Otherwise, i.e.Â if the robber never runs out of valid moves, the robber wins.
[Helicopter Cops and Robber game (the jump-searching version)]

Let G = (V, E) be a graph. G is called a planar
	graph , if there exists a planar embedding of G. An embedding of a graph G is 1-outerplanar , if it is
	planar, and all vertices lie on the exterior face. For k â‰¥ 2, an embedding
	of a graph G is k-outerplanar , if it is planar, and when
	all vertices on the outer face are deleted, then one obtains a
	(k-1)-outerplanar embedding of the resulting graph. If G admits a
	k-outerplanar embedding, then it is called a k-outerplanar graph .

[Cluster]
A k-clusterk-cluster C is a plane graph where all faces except one exterior face are triangles and that has the following properties:



  * All vertices of C have degree at most 6.


  * Vertices which are not on the boundary of C have degreeÂ 5 orÂ 6.


  * C contains exactly k vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary.


  * No two vertices with degreeÂ 5 which are not on the boundary are adjacent.


  * Vertices with degreeÂ 5 which are not on the boundary are at distance at least 2 from the boundary.


  * Between any two vertices a,b of C which have degreeÂ 5 and which are not on the boundary, there is a path P from a to b so that each edge on P contains exactly one vertex with degreeÂ 5 which is not in the boundary.


  * No subgraph of C is a k-cluster.

Let G_1 and G_2 be graphs with disjoint vertex-sets, let k â‰¥ 0 be an
  integer, and for i=1,2 let X_i âŠ† V(G_i) be a set of pairwise

  bijection, and let G be the graph obtained from the union of G_1' and
  G_2' by identifying x with f(x) for all x âˆˆ X_1. In those
  circumstances we say that G is a k-sum of G_1 and G_2.

Let G_1 and G_2 be graphs. A k-sum of G_1 and G_2 is any

  k-clique. (In particular, a 0-sum is a disjoint union.)

Let G be a graph with weighted vertices. Let vâˆˆ V(G) having weight one and tâˆˆâ„•. such that A Â· A âŠ† X Â· A.

A limit complex number X is said to be bounded if one has |X| â‰¤ C for some standard real number C, in which case we also write X=O(1) or |X| â‰ª 1.  More generally, given a limit complex number X and limit non-negative number Y, we write |X| â‰ª Y, Y â‰« |X|, or X = O(Y) if one has |X| â‰¤ CY for some standard real number C.  We write X = o(Y) if one has |X| â‰¤ Y for every standard > 0.  Observe that for any X, Y with Y positive, one has either |X| â‰« Y or X = o(Y).  We say that X is infinitesimal if X=o(1), and unbounded if 1/X = o(1).  Thus for instance any limit complex number X will either be bounded or unbounded.

The asymptotic notation X = O(Y), X â‰ª Y, Y = Î©(X), or Y â‰« X denotes the bound X â‰¤ CY for all n â‰¥ C and some absolute constant C; we also use X = Î˜(Y) for X â‰ª Y â‰ª X.  Subscripting such as O_d(Y) means that the implied constants C in the asymptotic notation are allowed to depend on d.

A limit complex number X is said to be bounded if one has |X| â‰¤ C for some standard real number C, in which case we also write X=O(1) or |X| â‰ª 1.  More generally, given a limit complex number X and limit non-negative number Y, we write |X| â‰ª Y, Y â‰« |X|, or X = O(Y) if one has |X| â‰¤ CY for some standard real number C.  We write X = o(Y) if one has |X| â‰¤ Y for every standard > 0.  Observe that for any X, Y with Y positive, one has either |X| â‰« Y or X = o(Y).  We say that X is infinitesimal if X=o(1), and unbounded if 1/X = o(1).  Thus for instance any limit complex number X will either be bounded or unbounded.

In a similar spirit, if x âˆˆ V is a limit element of a standard topological space V, we say that x is bounded if x is a limit element of standard compact subset K of V (i.e. x âˆˆ K), and unbounded otherwise.  The set of all bounded elements of V will be denoted V.

A nonstandard real number x âˆˆ is said to be bounded if one has |x| â‰¤ C for some standard C>0, and unbounded otherwise.  Similarly, we say that x is infinitesimal if |x| â‰¤ c for all standard c>0; in the former case we write x = O(1), and in the latter x=o(1).  For every bounded real number x âˆˆ there is a unique standard real number (x) âˆˆ, called the standard part of , such that x = (x)+o(1), or equivalently that (x) - â‰¤ x â‰¤(x)+ for all standard >0.  Indeed, one can set (x) to be the supremum of all the real numbers y such that x>y (or equivalently, the infimum of all the real numbers y such that x<y).

We write X = O(Y), X â‰ª Y, or Y â‰« X if we have X â‰¤ CY for some standard C; and we write X = o(Y), X  Y, or Y  X if we have X â‰¤ Y for every standard >0.

We use A â‰ª B or B â‰« A to denote the bound A â‰¤ CB for some constant C, and O(A) to denote any quantity bounded in magnitude by CA.  If we wish to allow the constant C to depend on auxiliary parameters, we will denote this by subscripts, e.g. O_Î·(A) denotes a quantity bounded by C_Î· A where C_Î· is allowed to depend on Î·.

An element Ïƒ of a poset P is called an atom of P, if
Ïƒ={Ïƒ}.
The set of all atoms of P will be denoted A(P).
A poset P is called atomic, if every its element is the least upper bound
of some subset of A(P).
[In the literature on lattice theory such posets are called â€œatomisticâ€,
whereas â€œatomicâ€ has a different meaning.
Our usage of the term can be found e.g. in <cit.>.]
It is easy to see that A(Ïƒ)=A(P)âˆ©Ïƒ.
Hence every element Ïƒ of an atomic poset is the least upper bound of
A(Ïƒ).

An element Ïƒ of a poset P is called an atom of P, if
Ïƒ={Ïƒ}.
The set of all atoms of P will be denoted A(P).
A poset P is called atomistic, if every its element is the least upper bound
of some set of atoms of P.
It is easy to see that A(Ïƒ)=A(P)âˆ©Ïƒ.
Hence every element Ïƒ of an atomistic poset is the least upper bound of
A(Ïƒ).
(Beware that â€œatomicâ€ has a different meaning in the literature on posets.)

We say that a Baxter permutation is a permutation that avoids the patterns 3-14-2 and 2-41-3, where an occurrence of the pattern 3-14-2 in a permutation w=w_1â€¦ w_n means there exists a quadruple of indices {i,j,j+1,k} with i<j<j+1<k and w_j< w_k< w_i< w_j+1 (and similarly for 2-14-3)[Such patterns with prescribed adjacencies are sometimes called vincular patterns.].

A permutation pâˆˆ_â„“ is called a Baxter permutation ,
  if there is no four-tuple of indices a<b<c<dâˆˆ [â„“] such that
  
  
  * c=b+1, and
  
  * the subpermutation p_a,p_b,p_c,p_d is order-isomorphic to 2413 or to 3142.
  
  In the terminology of Babson and SteingrÃ­mssonÂ <cit.>,
  Baxter permutations are exactly the permutations avoiding simultaneously the 
  two patterns 2-41-3 and 3-14-2.

If G is a graph with V(G)={v_1,...,v_n} then the
Boolean adjacency matrix of G is the nÃ— n matrix
ğ’œ(G) with the following entries in GF(2): ğ’œ
(G)_ii=1 if and only if v_i is looped, and if iâ‰  j then
ğ’œ(G)_ij=1 if and only if v_i is adjacent to v_j.

The Boolean adjacency matrix of a graph G is the symmetric
V(G)Ã— V(G) matrix ğ’œ(G) with entries in GF(2) given by: a
diagonal entry is 1 if and only if the corresponding vertex is looped in G,
and an off-diagonal entry is 1 if and only if the corresponding vertices are
neighbors in G.

Let G be a graph with V(G)={v_1, ..., v_n}.
The Boolean adjacency matrix of G is the nÃ— n matrix
ğ’œ(G) with entries in GF(2) defined by: if iâ‰  j then
ğ’œ(G)_ij=1 if and only if v_i is adjacent to v_j, and
ğ’œ(G)_ii=1 if and only if v_i is looped.

We say that (G, S, L) is a canvas if G is a plane graph, S is a subgraph of the boundary of the 
outer face of G, and L is a list assignment for the vertices of G such that |L(v)|â‰¥ 5 for all vâˆˆ V(G) 
not incident with the outer face,
|L(v)|â‰¥ 3 for all vâˆˆ V(G)âˆ– V(S), and there exists a proper L-coloring of S.

We say that (G, S, L) is a canvas if G is a plane graph of girth at least five, S is a subgraph of G, L is a list assignment for the vertices of G such that |L(v)|â‰¥ 3 for all vâˆˆ V(G)âˆ– V(S) and there exists an L-coloring of S. We call S the boundary of the canvas. We say a canvas (G,S,L) is critical if G is S-critical with respect to the list assignment L.

We say that (G, S, L) is a canvas if G is a plane graph, S is a subgraph of the boundary of the outer  face of G, and L is a list assignment for some supergraph of G such that |L(v)|â‰¥ 5 for all vâˆˆ V(G)- V(C), where C is the boundary of the outer  face of G, |L(v)|â‰¥ 3 for all vâˆˆ V(G)- V(S), and there exists a proper L-coloring of S.


Deleted: We say the canvas (G,S,L) is L-critical if there does not an exist an L-coloring of G but for every edge eâˆ‰E(S), there exists an L-coloring of Gâˆ– e, and for every vertex vâˆ‰V(S), there exists an L-coloring of Gâˆ– v.

Let G_1 = (V(G_1),E(G_1)) and G_2 = (V(G_2),E(G_2)) be two graphs. The Cartesian product G_1 Ã— G_2 (sometimes in the literature also denoted G_1 â–¡ G_2) is the graph with vertex set V(G_1) Ã— V(G_2), and vertices (u_1,v_1) and (u_2,v_2) are connected by an edge if  


  * either u_1 = u_2 and {v_1,v_2 }âˆˆ E(G_2),

  * or if v_1 = v_2 and {u_1, u_2 }âˆˆ E(G_1).
The Cartesian product G   H is the graph created by placing copies of G at all of the vertices of H and connecting corresponding vertices of adjacent G's in H.

Given two graphs G and H, their Cartesian product G  H  is defined as a graph with the
vertex set V(G) Ã— V(H) and the following set of edges,


    E(G  H) = (i_1,i_2),(j_1,j_2)(i_1,j_1) âˆˆ E(G)âˆ§ (i_2 = j_2) â‹(i_1 = j_1) âˆ§(i_2,j_2) âˆˆ E(H) .

where V(G  H)= V(G) Ã— V(H) and E(G  H)= {(u_1,v_1),(u_2,v_2)
|  u_1=u_2  and  (v_1,v_2)  âˆˆ E(H)
or  v_1=v_2  and  (u_1,u_2) âˆˆ E(G) }.

The Cartesian product of graphs G and H is the graph G  H such that:


  * The vertex set of G H is the Cartesian product V(G) Ã— V(H).

  * Two vertices (u,u') and (v,v') are adjacent in G H if and only if


  * u = v and u' is adjacent to v' in H, or

  * u' = v' and u is adjacent to v in G.

Let G and H be two disjoint graphs. The Cartesian product of G and H, denoted Gâ–¡ H, is defined by V(Gâ–¡ H)= V(G) Ã— V(H) and edges given by:


  * (x,y) is adjacent to (w,z) if x=w and y and z are adjacent in H, or

where x,w âˆˆ V(G) and y,zâˆˆ V(H).

Let G(V,E) be a graph and vâˆˆ V(G). The clique substitution at v is the graph obtain from G by replacing v with a clique of size |N_G(v)| and matching vertices in N_G(v) with the vertices of that clique. The clique substitution of G is the graph obtained from G by performing clique substitutions at all vertices of G. We refer to a clique substituted for a vertex of G as a knot (of K(G)).

Let G(V,E) be a graph and vâˆˆ V(G). The clique substitution at v is the graph obtain from G by replacing v with a clique of size |N_G(v)| and matching vertices in N_G(v) with the vertices of that clique. The clique substitution of G, denoted K(G), is the graph obtained from G by performing clique substitutions at all vertices of G. We refer to a clique substituted for a vertex of G as a knot (of K(G)).

A (symmetric) coset progression is a (multi-)subset[Strictly speaking, one should refer to the tuple (Q, H, r, (v_i)_i=1^r, (N_i)_i=1^r) as the coset progression, rather than just the multi-set Q, as one cannot define key concepts such as rank or the dilates Q without this additional data.  However, we shall abuse notation and use the multi-set Q as a metonym for the entire coset progression.] Q of an additive group G of the form

    Q = H + {n_1 v_1 + â€¦ + n_r v_r |n_i| â‰¤ N_i âˆ€ i=1,â€¦,r}

where H is a finite subgroup of G, r â‰¥ 0 is a non-negative integer (which we call the rank of Q), v_1,â€¦,v_r are elements of G, and N_1,â€¦,N_r > 0 are real numbers.  Here we count the sums n_1 v_1 + â€¦ + n_r v_r with multiplicity, and we view H as a multiset in which each element has an equal multiplicity (not necessarily 1).  Given any > 0, we define the dilate Q of Q by the formula

    Q   H + {n_1 v_1 + â€¦ + n_r v_r: |n_i| â‰¤ N_i âˆ€ i=1,â€¦,r}.

A (symmetric) coset progression in an abelian group G = (G,+) is any set of the form H+P, where H is a finite subgroup H of G, and P is a generalised arithmetic progression

    P = { n_1 v_1 + â€¦ + n_r v_r: n_i âˆˆ, |n_i| â‰¤ N_i  for all  1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ r }.

We refer to r as the rank of the coset progression.  If t â‰¥ 1, we say that the coset progression H+P is t-proper if the sums

    h + n_1 v_1 + â€¦ + n_r v_r

for h âˆˆ H, n_i âˆˆ, |n_i| â‰¤ tN_i are all distinct.  We say that a coset progression is proper if it is 1-proper.

We say that a limit subset H of a limit finite set X is dense if |H| â‰« |X|, and that a statement P(x) is true for many x âˆˆ X if it is true for all x in a dense subset H of X.  If instead |H| = o(|X|), we say that H is a sparse subset of X, and if P(x) only holds true for x in a sparse set, we say that P(x) only holds for few x âˆˆ X.  If the complement of H in X is sparse, we say that H is a co-sparse subset of X, and if P(x) holds for all x in a co-sparse subset, we say that P(x) holds for almost all x âˆˆ X.

Let log denote the logarithm to base 2 (choosing a different base would also yield a valid definition; it would change the value of entropy only by a multiplicative constant). Let XâŠ‚^ be a nonempty shift space and let m,nâˆˆ. Observe that every block wâˆˆ_m+n(X) can be written in a unique way as a concatenation w=uv, where uâˆˆ_m(X) and vâˆˆ_n(X). Therefore |_m+n(X)|â‰¤|_m(X)|Â· |_n(X)|, and hence

    log |_m+n(X)|â‰¤log|_m(X)|+log |_n(X)|.

By applying Fekete's Lemma to the nonnegative sequence log|_n(X)| we may now define the entropy of X , denoted by h(X), as

    h(X)=lim_nâ†’âˆ1/nlog |_n(X)|=inf_nâ‰¥ 11/nlog |_n(X) |.

Let A be a non-empty limit finite set, and let B be a finite set.  A limit map f: A â†’ B is said to be equidistributed if one has

A finite collection of functions f_i:A â†’ B_i, i=1,â€¦,k into finite sets B_i is said to be jointly equidistributed if the combined function (f_1,â€¦,f_k): A â†’ B_1 Ã—â€¦Ã— B_k is jointly equidistributed.

Let G/Î“ be a standard nilmanifold, which then admits a canonical Haar probability measure Î¼.  Let Î© be a non-empty limit finite set, and let : Î©â†’ (G/Î“) be a limit function.  We say that  is equidistributed in G/Î“ if, for every F âˆˆ(G/Î“), one has

Now we specialise to the case Î©=[N]^k.  We say that  is totally equidistributed on [N]^k if it is equidistributed on every product P_1 Ã—â€¦Ã— P_k of dense arithmetic progressions P_1,â€¦,P_k in [N], thus

Let G = (V, E) be a bipartite graph with bipartition V = X âŠ” Y.  Then G is a Ferrers graph if and only if any of the following equivalent conditions hold:


  * There exist a vertex weighting w and a real number T such that for any u vâˆˆ V, the vertices u and v are adjacent if and only if |w(u) - w(v)| â‰¥ T.


  * The graph G' constructed from G by adding all possible edges between vertices in X is a threshold graph.


  * The graph G contains no induced 2K_2.


  * The neighborhoods of vertices in X are linearly ordered by inclusion.


  * The degree sequences for vertices in X and vertices in Y are conjugate.

Let e=(u,v) and f be edges of a phylogenetic network. A head move of e to f consists of the following steps:


  * removal of edge e,

  * subdividing f with a new node v',

  * suppressing the in-degree 1, out-degree 1 node v,

  * adding the edge (u,v').

Head moves are only allowed if the resulting digraph is a phylogenetic network.
We say that the move is over distance d if there is a path from v to v' of graph length d+1 in the underlying undirected graph where both nodes exist (after step 2).

Let Î“ be a finite graph with vertex set S. A heap of type Î“ (or Î“-heap) is a finite poset (H,â‰¤), together with a labeling map Ïµ:Hâ†’Î“, which satisfies the following conditions:


  *  For any vertex s, the subposet H_s:=Ïµ^-1({s}) is totally ordered, and for any edge {s,t}, the subposet H_{s,t}:=Ïµ^-1({s,t}) is totally ordered.

  *  The ordering on H is the transitive closure of the relations given by all chains H_s and H_{s,t}, i.e. the smallest partial ordering containing these chains.

Let Î“ be a finite graph with vertex set S. A heap on Î“ (or of type Î“) is a finite poset (H,â‰¤), together with a labeling map Ïµ:Hâ†’Î“, which satisfies the following conditions:



  * For any vertex s, the subposet H_s:=Ïµ^-1({s}) is totally ordered, and for any edge {s,t}, the subposet H_{s,t}:=Ïµ^-1({s,t}) is totally ordered.

  * The ordering on H is the transitive closure of the relations given by all chains H_s and H_{s,t}, i.e. the smallest partial ordering containing these chains.

Given a sequence (x_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜, we define their ultralimit lim_â†’Î± x_ to be the equivalence class of all sequences (y_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜ such that x_ = y_ for  sufficiently close to Î±. An ultralimit of standard natural numbers is known as a limit natural number , an ultralimit of standard real numbers is known as a limit real number , etc.

For any standard object x, we identify x with its own ultralimit lim_â†’Î± x.  Thus, every standard natural number is a limit natural number, etc.

Any operation or relation on standard objects can be extended to limit objects in the obvious manner.  For instance, the sum of two limit real numbers lim_â†’Î± x_, lim_â†’Î± y_ is the limit real number

    lim_â†’Î± x_ + lim_â†’Î± y_ = lim_â†’Î± x_ + y_,

and the statement lim_â†’Î± x_ < lim_â†’Î± y_ means that x_ < y_ for all  sufficiently close to Î±.

Given a sequence (x_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜, we define their ultralimit lim_â†’ p x_ to be the equivalence class of all sequences (y_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜ such that x_ = y_ for  sufficiently close to p.  Note that the ultralimit lim_â†’ p x_ can also be defined even if x_ is only defined for  sufficiently close to p.

An ultralimit of standard natural numbers is known as a limit natural number , an ultralimit of standard real numbers is known as a limit real number , etc.

For any standard object x, we identify x with its own ultralimit lim_â†’ p x.  Thus, every standard natural number is a limit natural number, etc.

Any operation or relation on standard objects can be extended to limit objects in the obvious manner.  For instance, the sum of two limit real numbers lim_â†’ p x_, lim_â†’ p y_ is the limit real number

    lim_â†’ p x_ + lim_â†’ p y_ = lim_â†’ p x_ + y_,

and the statement lim_â†’ p x_ < lim_â†’ p y_ means that x_ < y_ for all  sufficiently close to p.

Let (X_)_âˆˆ be a sequence of standard spaces X_ in ğ”˜ indexed by the natural numbers.  The ultrapower âˆ_â†’ p X_ of the X_ is defined to be the space of all ultralimits lim_â†’ p x_, where x_âˆˆ X_ for all .  Note X_ only needs to be well-defined for  sufficiently close to p in order for the ultraproduct to be well-defined.  If X is a set, the set âˆ_â†’ p X is known as the ultrapower of X and is denoted X.  Thus for instance  is the space of all limit natural numbers,  is the space of all limit reals, etc.

We define a limit set to be an ultraproduct of sets, a limit group to be an ultraproduct of groups, a limit finite set to be an ultraproduct of finite sets, and so forth.  A limit subset of a limit set X = âˆ_â†’ p X_ is a limit set of the form Y = âˆ_â†’ p Y_, where Y_ is a standard subset of X_ for all  sufficiently close to p.

Given a sequence of standard functions f_: X_â†’ Y_ between standard sets X_, Y_, we can form the ultralimit f = lim_â†’ p f_ to be the function f: âˆ_â†’ p X_â†’âˆ_â†’ p Y_ defined by the formula

We refer to f as a limit function or limit map , and say that f(x) depends in a limit fashion on x.

A Lyndon word is a nonempty word w âˆˆ A^* such that every nonempty proper suffix v of w satisfies w <_A v.  Let â„’ denote the set of all Lyndon words.

A cyclic shift of a word P is a word of the form VU if P=UV.
A non-empty word P is Lyndon if it is strictly smaller in the lexicographic order than all of its cyclic shifts.

A tree decomposition (T = (N, F), X) of a graph G = (V, E) is called
 	existentially MSOL-definable , if the following are
 	existentially MSOL-definable (with parameters x_1,â€¦,x_p for some
 	constant p).

















 	
 	  
  * Each bag X_p, p âˆˆ N in the tree decomposition is associated with
 	  either a vertex v âˆˆ V or an edge e âˆˆ E (called its
 	  witness ) and can be identified by one of the following predicates
 	  (where S âŠ† V and s and t are constants).
 	  
 	    
  * _Ï„_1(v, S),â€¦,_Ï„_t(v, S): The vertex set
 	    S forms a bag in the tree decomposition of G, i.e. 	    S = X_p for some p âˆˆ N, it is of type Ï„_i (1 â‰¤ i â‰¤
 	    t) and its witness is v.



 	    
  * _Ïƒ_1(e, S),â€¦,_Ïƒ_s(e, S): The vertex set
 	    S forms a bag in the tree decomposition of G, i.e. S = X_p for some
 	    p âˆˆ N, it is of type Ïƒ_i (1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ s) and its
 	    witness is e.
 	  
 		
  * Each edge in F can be identified with a predicate (S_p,
 		S_c), where S_p, S_c âŠ† V: The vertex sets S_p and S_c form
 		bags in (T, X), i.e. S_p = X_p and S_c = X_c for some p, c âˆˆ N,
 		and p is the parent node of c in T.

A rooted (and ordered) tree decomposition (T, X) of a graph G is called
	MSOL-definable , if the following hold.
	
	  
  * Each bag X in the tree decomposition can be identified by one of the
	  following predicates (where s and t are constants). 
	  
	    
  * _Ï„_1^V(v, X),â€¦,_Ï„_t^V(v, X): The bag X is
	    associated with type Ï„_i and the vertex v âˆˆ V, where 1 â‰¤ i â‰¤
	    t.
	    
  * _Ïƒ_1^E(e, X),â€¦,_Ïƒ_s^E(e, X): The bag X
	    is associated with type Ïƒ_j and the edge e âˆˆ E, where 1 â‰¤ j
	    â‰¤ s.
	  
	  Furthermore there
	  exists at least one type that contains the corresponding vertex or both
	  endpoints of the corresponding edge.
		
  * There exists a predicate (X_p, X_c) to identify edges in T,
		which is true, if and only if X_p is the parent bag of X_c.
	
	We call an MSOL-definable tree decomposition ordered , if the following
	holds. 
	
	  
	  
  * There exists a predicate (X_l, X_r), which is true if and only
	  if X_l and X_r are siblings such that X_l is the direct left sibling of
		X_r.

<cit.> Let G be a simple graph. For each pair of
distinct vertices v and w of G, let Î²(v,w) and Î²(w,v) be
distinct variables. Then the Naji equations for G are the following.

(a) For each edge vw of G, Î²(v,w)+Î²(w,v)=1.

(b) If v,w,x are three distinct vertices of G such that vwâˆˆ E(G) and
vx,wxâˆ‰ E(G), then Î²(x,v)+Î²(x,w)=0.

(c) If v,w,x are three distinct vertices of G such that vw,vxâˆˆ E(G)
and wxâˆ‰ E(G), then Î²(v,w)+Î²(v,x)+Î²(w,x)+Î²(x,w)=1.

Let G be a simple graph. For each pair of
distinct vertices v and w of G, let Î²(v,w) and Î²(w,v) be
distinct variables. Then the Naji equations for G are the following.


  * If vw is an edge of G then Î²(v,w)+Î²(w,v)=1.


  * If v,w,x are three distinct vertices of G such that vw is an edge of G and vx,wx are not edges of G, then Î²(x,v)+Î²(x,w)=0.


  * If v,w,x are three distinct vertices of G such that vw,vx are edges of G and wx is not an edge of G, then Î²(v,w)+Î²(v,x)+Î²(w,x)+Î²(x,w)=1.
The Newton polytope of a monomial ideal I in k[x_1,â€¦ x_n] is the polytope Newt(I) in â„^n spanned by the exponent vectors of the generators of I.

The Newton polytope of a Laurent polynomial is the convex hull of all the exponent vectors of the monomials, i.e. the convex hull of all points (c_1,c_2,. . .) such that the monomial x_1^c_1 x_2^c_2 . . . appears with a nonzero coefficient in the Laurent polynomial.

Let x_1,â€¦,x_r be elements that generate an s-step nilpotent group and let L=(L_1,â€¦,L_r) be a vector of positive integers. Then the set of all products in the x_i and their inverses in which each x_i and its inverse appear at most L_i times between them is called a nilprogression of rank r, step s and side lengths L_1,â€¦,L_r, and is denoted P^*(x_1,â€¦,x_r;L).

Suppose that G is a local group and that s â‰¥ 0 is an integer. A nilprogression of rank r and s is a non-commutative progression P(u_1,â€¦ ,u_r;N_1,â€¦ ,N_r) with the property that every iterated commutator of degree s+1 in the generators u_1,â€¦ ,u_r is well-defined and equals the identity ğ•€.

A 2-step nilmanifold is a homogeneous space G/Î“, where G is a nilpotent Lie groups of step at most 2, and Î“ is a discrete cocompact subgroup.  A fundamental 2-step nilmanifold is one of the following three examples of a 2-step nilmanifold:


  *  G = and Î“ =.

  *  G = ([ 1    ; 0 1  ; 0 0 1 ]) and Î“ = ([ 1    ; 0 1  ; 0 0 1 ]).

  *  G = ([ 1    ; 0 1  ; 0 0 1 ]) and Î“ = ([ 1    ; 0 1  ; 0 0 1 ]).

We place smooth metrics on each of these nilmanifolds; the exact choice of metric is not important. An elementary 2-step nilmanifold is a Cartesian product of finitely many fundamental 2-step nilmanifolds, with the product metric. Again, the exact convention for defining the product metric is not important.  An elementary 2-step nilsequence is a sequence of the form n â†¦ F(g^n x_0), where G/Î“ is an elementary 2-step nilmanifold, F: G/Î“â†’ is a Lipschitz function, g âˆˆ G, and x_0 âˆˆÎ“.

A periodic parallelogram polyomino is a PP with an admissible marked
cell in the first column. A cell is called admissible if its height is less or
equal to the size of the last column.

A periodic parallelogram polyomino is a parallelogram polyomino P
    with a positive integer g called the gluing size , such that g is
    smaller or equal to the minimum of the heights of the first and last column
    of P. Moreover, in the rest of the article we consider PPP's which are
    not of rectangular shape with gluing size equal to the size of the columns.

Let P G â†’ K be a function from one additive group G = (G,+) to another K = (K,+).  For any subgroup H of G and for any integer d, we say that P is a polynomial of degree <d along H according to the following recursive definition[Our conventions here are somewhat nonstandard, but are chosen so that the proofs of our main theorems, such as Theorem <ref>, resemble the proofs of warmup results such as Proposition <ref>.]:


  (i)  If d â‰¤ 0, we say that P is of degree <d along H if and only if it is identically zero.

  (ii)  If d â‰¥ 1, we say that P is of degree <d along H if and only if, for each h âˆˆ H, there exists a polynomial P_h: G â†’ K of degree <d-1 along H such that 

    P(x+h) = P(x) + P_h(x)

for all x âˆˆ G.

for all h_1,â€¦,h_d+1,n âˆˆ V, where _h f(n) := (T_h - 1) f(n) = f(n+h)-f(n) is the additive derivative of f in the direction h.  We adopt the convention that the zero polynomial 0 has degree -âˆ.  We denote the space of all polynomials of degree â‰¤ d as _â‰¤ d(V â†’ G); this is clearly an additive group, with _â‰¤ d(V â†’ G) = {0} for d<0.

A quiver Q is a directed graph, along with a Laurent polynomial label at every vertex. The variable v denotes the number of vertices in Q, or |Q|. The directed graph must have no 2-cycles.

A quiver Q is a directed graph; we will assume that Q has no 
loops or 2-cycles.
If there are i arrows from vertex Î» to Î¼, then 
we will set b_Î»Î¼ = i and b_Î¼Î» = -i.
Each vertex is designated either  mutable or frozen .
The skew-symmetric matrix B = (b_Î»Î¼) is called the exchange matrix of Q.

Mutating at a vertex i in Q is denoted by Î¼_i and corresponds to the following actions on the quiver:


  * For every 2-path through i (e.g. jâ†’ iâ†’ k), add an edge from j to k.

  * Reverse the directions of the arrows incident to i.

  * Delete any 2-cycles created from the previous two steps.

Correspondingly, the cluster variable at vertex i is updated and all other cluster variables stay the same. The update follows this binomial exchange relation:

    x_i'x_i=âˆ_iâ†’ j in Qx_j^a_iâ†’ j+âˆ_jâ†’ i in Qx_j^a_jâ†’ i,

where x_i' is the new cluster variable at vertex i and a_iâ†’ j is the number of edges from i to j.

Let Î» be a mutable vertex of quiver Q.  The quiver mutation 
_Î» transforms Q into a new quiver Q' = _Î»(Q) via a sequence of three steps:


  * For each oriented two path Î¼â†’Î»â†’Î½, add a new arrow Î¼â†’Î½
(unless Î¼ and Î½ are both frozen, in which case do nothing).

  * Reverse the direction of all arrows incident to the vertex Î».

  * Repeatedly remove oriented 2-cycles until unable to do so.

	If B is the exchange matrix of Q, then we let _Î»(B) denote the 
	exchange matrix of _Î»(Q).

An quiver mutation at vertex i is defined by changing both the quiver around vertex i and the Laurent polynomial at vertex i. The quiver changes are defined as follows.


  * For every path j â†’ i â†’ k, draw a new edge from j to k.

  * For every path j â†’ i â†’ k, draw a new edge from j to k. Reverse the direction of every edge pointing with i as a vertex.

  * Delete all 2-cycles.

The Laurent polynomial is replaced as follows. Let V_k denote the Laurent polynomial currently on vertex k. Replace V_i with the following polynomial P. 
    P=âˆ_j âˆˆ S_1V_j + âˆ_j âˆˆ S_2V_j/V_i
 where S_1 is the multiset of edges pointing into i attached to i and S_2 is the multiset of edges pointing out of i.

Apply LemmaÂ <ref> to the graph G=(V,E) with parameters Îµ and d, 
and denote the clusters of the resulting partition by V_0, V_1,â€¦,V_â„“, V_0 being

are the vertices of the reduced graph (hence |V(G_r)|=â„“). We connect two vertices of

pair with density at least d.

Apply <ref> to the graph G=(W,E) with parameters Îµ and d, 
and denote the clusters of the resulting partition by W_0, W_1,â€¦, W_â„“ (W_0 being the exceptional cluster). We construct a new graph G_r, the reduced graph of G' in
the following way: The non-exceptional clusters of G'
are the vertices of the reduced graph G_r (hence v(G_r)=â„“). We connect two vertices of

In what follows we consider the set â„±( A) of permuted rooted forests composed of:


  * a bicolored identified ordered seed tree with a white root vertex,

  * other bicolored ordered trees, called non-seed trees  with either a white or a black root vertex,

  * each vertex of the forest has three kind of ordered descendants: tree-edges (connecting a white and a black vertex), thorns (half edges connected to only one vertex) and loops connecting a vertex to itself. The two extremities of the loop are part of the ordered set of descendants of the incident vertex and therefore the loop can be intersected by thorns, edges and other loops as well.

The forests in â„±( A) also have the following properties:


  * the root vertices of the non-seed trees have at least one descending loop with one extremity being the rightmost descendant of the considered vertex,

  * the total number of thorns (resp. loops) connected to the white vertices is equal to the number of thorns (resp. loops) connected to the black ones,


  * there is a bijection between thorns connected to white vertices and the thorns connected to black vertices. The bijection between thorns will be encoded by assigning the same symbolic latin labels {a,b,c,â€¦} to thorns associated by this bijection,

  * there is a mapping that associates to each loop incident to a white (resp. black) vertex, a black (resp. white) vertex v  such that the number of white (resp. black) loops associated to a fixed black (resp. white) vertex v is equal to its number of incident loops. We will use symbolic greek labels {Î±,Î²,â€¦} to associate loops with vertices except for the maximal loop (i.e. the loop whose rightmost extremity is the rightmost descendant of the considered vertex) of a root vertex r of the non-seed trees. In this case, we draw an arrow ( [very thick,densely dashed] [->] (0,0) to (0.8,0);   ) outgoing from the root vertex r and incoming to the vertex associated with the loop. Arrows are non ordered, and :

  * the ascendant/descendant structure defined by the edges of the forest and the arrows defined above is a tree structure rooted in the root of the seed tree.

Finally the degree A of the forest is given in the following way:


  (vii) P_ij (resp P'_ij) counts the number of non root white vertices (resp. white root vertices excluding the root of the seed tree) of degree i with a total number of j loops,

  (viii) Q_ij (resp Q'_ij) counts the number of non root black vertices (resp. black root vertices) of degree i with a total number of j loops.
plain_text_term: Rooted bicolored forests of degree A

plain_text_def:
In what follow we consider the set â„±( A) of permuted rooted forests composed of:


  * a bicolored identified ordered seed tree with a white root vertex,

  * other bicolored ordered trees, called non-seed trees  with either a white or a black root vertex,

  * each vertex of the forest has three kinds of ordered descendants : tree-edges or edges (connecting a white and a black vertex), thorns (halves of tree-edges connected to only one vertex) and loops connecting a vertex to itself. The two extremities of the loop are part of the ordered set of descendants of the incident vertex and therefore the loop can be intersected by thorns, edges and other loops as well.

The forests in â„±( A) also have the following properties:
[(i)]

  * the root vertices of the non-seed trees have at least one descending loop with one extremity being the rightmost descendant of the considered vertex,

  * the total number of thorns (resp. loops) connected to the white vertices is equal to the number of thorns (resp. loops) connected to the black vertices,


  * there is a bijection between thorns connected to white vertices and the thorns connected to black vertices. The bijection between thorns will be encoded by assigning the same symbolic latin labels {a,b,c,â€¦} to thorns associated by this bijection,

  * there is a mapping that associates to each loop incident to a white (resp. black) vertex, a black (resp. white) vertex v  such that the number of white (resp. black) loops associated to a fixed black (resp. white) vertex v is equal to its number of incident loops. We will use symbolic greek labels {Î±,Î²,â€¦} to associate loops with vertices except for the maximal loop of a root vertex r of the non-seed trees. In this case, we draw an arrow ( [very thick,densely dashed] [->] (0,0) to (0.8,0);   ) outgoing from the root vertex r and incoming to the vertex associated with the loop. Arrows are non ordered, and

  * the ascendant/descendant structure defined by the edges of the forest and the arrows defined above is a tree structure rooted in the root of the seed tree.


Finally the degree A of the forest is given in the following way:


  (vii) P_ijk (resp P'_ijk) counts the number of non root white vertices (including the root of the seed tree) (resp. white root vertices excluding the root of the seed tree) of degree i, with j incoming arrows and a total of j+k loops.

  (viii) Q_ijk (resp Q'_ijk) counts the number of non root black vertices (resp. black root vertices) of degree i, with j incoming arrows and total j+k loops.
plain_text_term: Rooted bicolored forests of degree A

A separation of a graphÂ G is a pair (A, B) such that

The Strahler number of a node x in a directed tree T is a number defined by a bottom-up calculation in the tree, as follows: if x is a leaf, its Strahler number is one. Otherwise, let s be the largest Strahler number of a child ofÂ x. If x has only one child with Strahler numberÂ s, its Strahler number is alsoÂ s, and if x has multiple children with Strahler numberÂ s, then its Strahler number isÂ s+1.

Switching a signed graph means reversing the signs of all edges between a vertex subset W âŠ† V and its complement, V-W.  (The negated edge set may be void.)  We note that switching does not change the sign of a closed chain.

Let e=(u,v) and f be edges of a phylogenetic network. A tail move of e to f consists of the following steps:


  * removal of edge e,

  * subdividing f with a new node u',

  * suppressing the in-degree 1, out-degree 1 node u,

  * adding the edge (u',v).

Tail moves are only allowed if the resulting digraph is a phylogenetic network.
We say that the move is over distance d if there is a path from u to u' of graph length d+1 in the underlying undirected graph where both nodes exist (after step 2).

Given a templateÂ tâˆˆ(2^[k]âˆ–{âˆ…})^K_n, we say that a k-colouringÂ câˆˆ[k]^K_n realises t if c(e)âˆˆ t(e) for every edgeÂ eâˆˆ E(K_n).  We write âŸ¨ t âŸ© for the collection of realisations ofÂ t and câˆˆâŸ¨ tâŸ©  as a shorthand for `c is a realisation of t'.

A connected and locally finite planar graph G is a planar tessellation , or just tessellation , if it satisfies the following conditions.



  (i) Every edge is contained in exactly two different faces.

  (ii) Every bounded face is a polygon: it is homeomorphic to the closed disk ğ”», and its boundary is a simple cycle (i.e. a finite path in which the first and the last vertices coincide). The edges of the cycle are called sides of the polygon.

  (iii) The intersection of any two distinct faces are either an empty set, or a vertex, or an edge.

A tree decomposition of a graph G = (V, E) is a pair (T, X) of a
	tree T = (N, F) and an indexed family of vertex sets (X_t)_t âˆˆ N
	(called bags ), such that the following properties hold.
	
	  
  * Each vertex v âˆˆ V is contained in at least one bag.
	  
  * For each edge e âˆˆ E there exists a bag containing both endpoints.
	  
  * For each vertex v âˆˆ V, the bags in the tree decomposition that
	  contain v form a subtree of T.
	
	The width of a tree decomposition is the size of the largest bag minus 1
	and the treewidth of a graph is the minimum width of all its tree
	decompositions.

A tree decomposition of a graph G = (V, E) is a pair (T, X) of a
	tree T = (N, F) and an indexed family of vertex sets (X_t)_t âˆˆ N
	(called bags ), such that the following properties hold.
	
	  
  * Each vertex v âˆˆ V is contained in at least one bag.
	  
  * For each edge e âˆˆ E there exists a bag containing both endpoints.
	  
  * For each vertex v âˆˆ V, the bags in the tree decomposition that
	  contain v form a subtree of T.
	
	The width of a tree decomposition is the size of the largest bag minus 1
	and the treewidth of a graph is the minimum width of all its tree
	decompositions. We might sometimes refer to graphs of treewidth at most k as
	partial k-trees .[For several characterizations of graphs of
	treewidth at most k, see e.g. <cit.>]

Let G be a simple graph. A tree decomposition of G is a tree
T, where each node (also called a bucket ) corresponds to a subset
of the vertices of G, with the following properties:

  
  * For each vertex v of G, the buckets in which v appears
    form a non-empty, connected subgraph of T.
  
  * For each edge e of G, there exists a bucket that contains both
    endpoints of e.

The width of a tree decomposition of G is the size of the biggest
bucket minus one.
The treewidth of G denoted by (G) is the smallest possible width
of a tree decomposition of G.

A tree decomposition of a graph G is a tree T=(B,E) whose vertices {B_i   |   i âˆˆ I} are called bags . 
Each bag B_i is a subset of vertices of G, and we require that:

	
  * every vertex of G is contained in at least one bag (vertex coverage);
	
  * for each edge of G, at least one bag must contains both its endpoints (edge coverage); 
	
  * the induced subgraph of T spanned by all bags sharing a given vertex of G
	must form a subtree of T (subtree property).


The width of a tree decomposition is defined as max |B_i|-1, and the 
treewidth of G is the minimum width over all tree decompositions.

Let (X_)_âˆˆ be a sequence of standard spaces X_ in ğ”˜ indexed by the natural numbers.  The ultraproduct âˆ_â†’Î± X_ of the X_ is defined to be the space of all ultralimits lim_â†’Î± x_, where x_âˆˆ X_ for all .  We refer to the ultraproduct of standard sets as an nonstandard set ; in a similar vein, an ultraproduct of standard groups is a nonstandard group , and an ultraproduct of standard finite sets is a nonstandard finite set .  We refer to X := âˆ_â†’Î± X as the ultrapower of a standard set X; the identification of x with lim_â†’Î± x causes X to be identified with a subset of X.  We will refer to the ultrapower  ğ”˜ of the standard universe ğ”˜ as the nonstandard universe .

Let (X_)_âˆˆ be a sequence of standard spaces X_ in ğ”˜ indexed by the natural numbers.  The ultraproduct âˆ_â†’Î± X_ of the X_ is defined to be the space of all ultralimits lim_â†’Î± x_, where x_âˆˆ X_ for all .  We refer to the ultraproduct of standard sets as an nonstandard set ; in a similar vein, an ultraproduct of standard finite sets is a nonstandard finite set , and an ultraproduct of standard finite fields is a nonstandard finite field .  We refer to X := âˆ_â†’Î± X as the ultrapower of a standard set X; the identification of x with lim_â†’Î± x causes X to be identified with a subset of X.  We will refer to the ultrapower  ğ”˜ of the standard universe ğ”˜ as the nonstandard universe .

In a similar spirit, if f_: X_â†’ Y_ is a collection of standard functions between standard sets X_,Y_, we can form the ultralimit f := lim_â†’Î± f_ to be the function from X := âˆ_â†’Î± X_ to Y := âˆ_â†’Î± Y_ defined by the formula

    f( lim_â†’Î± x_n ) := lim_â†’Î± f_(x_).

We refer to such functions as nonstandard functions (also known as internal functions in the nonstandard analysis literature).

As with nonstandard objects, any operation or relation on standard spaces can be converted to a nonstandard analogue in the usual manner.  For instance, the nonstandard cardinality of a nonstandard finite set X = âˆ_â†’Î± X_ is the nonstandard natural number

    |X| := lim_â†’Î± |X_|.

Note that this is a different concept from the usual (or external ) cardinality of X; indeed, nonstandard finite sets usually have an uncountable external cardinality.  Similarly, if f: X â†’ is a nonstandard function f = lim_â†’Î± f_ defined on a nonstandard finite set X = âˆ_â†’Î± X_, we can define the nonstandard sum âˆ‘_x âˆˆ X f(x) to be the nonstandard real number

    âˆ‘_x âˆˆ X f(x) := lim_â†’Î±âˆ‘_x_âˆˆ X_ f_(x_).

A projective algebraic set (resp. affine algebraic set ) is a subset V of a projective space ^N (resp. affine space ^N) of the form

    V = { x âˆˆ^N: P_1(x) = â€¦ = P_J(x) = 0 }

where P_1,â€¦,P_J are homogeneous polynomials (resp. polynomials).  A projective (resp. affine) algebraic set is called irreducible if it cannot be written as the union of two proper projective (resp. affine) algebraic subsets, in which case we refer to the algebraic set as a variety .

The dimension of an algebraic set V is the smallest integer d such that intersections of V with generic codimension-d subspaces of ^N or ^N are finite.  If V is a projective variety of dimension d, then generic codimension d subspaces of ^N intersect V in a constant number of points, known as the degree of V.  Every affine variety can be embedded in a unique projective variety of the same dimension (the projective closure of the affine variety); we define the degree of the affine variety to be that of its projective closure.

  The definitions given here are classical in style, and thus subject to certain pathologies; for instance, one might expect the vanishing locus of a degree-d polynomial in 2 variables to be a curve of degree d, and this is generically the case: but if the polynomial is, for instance, (x+y)^d, then the vanishing locus is (according to our definition) a curve of degree 1.  Problems of this kind will change degrees at worst by bounded multiplicative constants, so we will systematically ignore them; in any event, all proofs in the paper work when the better-behaved scheme-theoretic definitions of dimension and degree are used.



Given a projective (resp. affine) algebraic set V, we define its set of  F-points V(F) to be the set V(F) = V âˆ©^n(F) (resp. V(F) = V âˆ©^n(F)).

An irreducible curve is an algebraic variety of dimension one.  A hypersurface in an algebraic variety V of degree n is a subvariety of V whose dimension is n-1.

An (affine) variety defined over k is a subset V âŠ† k^n of the form

    V = { x âˆˆ k^n: P_1(x) = â€¦ = P_m(x) = 0 }

where n,m are natural numbers, and P_1,â€¦,P_m: k^n â†’ k are polynomials.  We say that the variety has complexity at most M if n,m are at most M, and all the degrees of P_1,â€¦,P_m are at most M.  If furthermore the polynomials P_1,â€¦,P_m have coefficients defined over F, we say that V is defined over F (with complexity at most M).   A variety is (geometrically) irreducible if it cannot be expressed as the union of two strictly smaller subvarieties.

The Zariski closure of a subset E of k^n is defined to be the intersection of all the varieties in k^n that contain E.

The dimension of a non-empty variety V âŠ‚ k^n is the largest natural number d for which one has a chain

    âˆ…âŠŠ V_0 âŠŠâ€¦âŠŠ V_d âŠ‚ V

of irreducible varieties V_0,â€¦,V_d.  We adopt the convention that the empty set has dimension -âˆ.

A walk of length n is a sequence P=(P_0,P_1,â€¦,P_n) of points in â„•^2 with its n steps in the set {(1,1),(1,-1),(1,0)}, such that P_0 has abscissa 0 and all horizontal steps (1,0) can only occur between points on the x-axis.

A walk of length n is a sequence P=(P_0,P_1,â€¦,P_n) of points in â„•^2 with its n steps in the set {(1,1),(1,-1),(1,0)}, such that P_0 has abscissa 0 and all horizontal steps (1,0) are labeled either by L or R. A walk is said to satisfy condition (*) if all horizontal steps of the form (i,0)â†’ (i+1,0) have label L.

[Talagrand's Inequality]
Let X be a non-negative random variable, not identically 0, which is determined by
l independent trials T_1,â€¦,T_l, and satisfying the following for some c,k>0:


  1. changing the outcome of any one trial can affect X by at most c, and

  2. for any s, if Xâ‰¥ s then there is a set of at most ks trials whose outcomes certify that Xâ‰¥ s,

then for any 0â‰¤ tâ‰¤ğ„(X),

    Pr(|X-E(X)|>t+60câˆš(kE(X)))â‰¤ 4e^-t^2/8c^2kğ„(X).

[Talagrand's Inequality]
Let X be a non-negative random variable determined by l independent trials T_1,â€¦,T_l. 
Suppose there exist constants c,k>0 such that for every set of possible outcomes of the trials, we have:


  1. changing the outcome of any one trial can affect X by at most c, and

  2. for each s>0, if Xâ‰¥ s then there is a set of at most ks trials whose outcomes certify that Xâ‰¥ s. 

Then for any tâ‰¥ 0, we have

    Pr(|X-E(X)|>t+20câˆš(kE(X))+64c^2k)â‰¤ 4e^-t^2/8c^2k(ğ„(X)+t).

Let Î” be a strongly connected quasi-tree with the leaf order F_1,â€¦,F_m. We define a relation tree of Î” , denoted by T(Î”), in the following way:

Let G be a directed graph.
The adjacency matrix , A_G, of G
is the

entry is the number of directed edges whose tail is the vertex v_1 and
whose 
head is the vertex v_2.

of G is the number
of edges whose head (respectively tail) is v.

The adjacency matrix of an undirected graph, G, is
simply the adjacency matrix of its underlying directed graph. 
For an undirected graph, the indegree of any vertex equals its outdegree,
and is just called its degree.
The degree matrix of G is the diagonal matrix, 
D_G, indexed on V_G
whose (v,v) entry is the degree of v.
We say that G is d-regular if D_G is d times the identity
matrix, i.e., if each vertex of G has degree d.

Often, some alternative property is imposed: Lie algebras, in which the Jacobi identity is enforced, have a structure theory analogous to what we discuss in this section.]) algebra over the field k is a vector space ğ’œ over k together with a binary operation (multiplication) which satisfies the following conditions:

A finite word w with alphabet (w) :=, || â‰¥ 2, is said to be a generalized trapezoidal word (or GT-word for short) if there exist positive integers m, M with m â‰¤ M such that the factor complexity funtion C_w(n) of w increases by 1 for each n in the interval [1,m], is constant for each n in the interval [m,M], and decreases by 1 for each n in the interval [M,|w|]. That is, w is a GT-word if there exist positive integers m, M with m â‰¤ M such that C_w satisfies the following:



C_w(0)=1,    Â  
 
C_w(i) = || + i - 1    Â  for 1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ m, 

C_w(i+1)=C_w(i)        Â  for m â‰¤ i â‰¤ M-1, 

C_w(i+1)=C_w(i)-1      Â  for M â‰¤ i â‰¤ |w|.

An alternating sign matrix (ASM) is a square matrix with entries 0, 1, or -1 whose rows and columns each sum to 1 and such that the nonzero entries in each row and column alternate in sign.

An alternating sign matrix (ASM) is a (0,1,-1)-matrix in which all row and column sums are 1, and the non-zero elements in each row and column alternate in sign.

[Local exchange. Closure]

Let H be a trigraph, H_0 be an induced cycle of H and let S be a set of disjoint paths of H on 3 vertices. 
Let â„‹=(H_0, H_i, L_i)^n  be an ear decomposition of H that admits H_0, S. 


  * A local exchange on the pair H, â„‹
is an operation that produces a pair H', (H_0, H'_i, L'_i)^n of a trigraph with its ear decomposition (see FigureÂ <ref>) as follows:
Let L_i_0âˆˆ{L_1,â€¦, L_n} be a 3-ear antenna with vertices a, w_1, w_2, w_3, b. 
Let (L_i_j)_j âˆˆ [l] be a heel such that the leaves of L_i_1 are w_2, w_3,
and let u be the internal vertex of L_i_l that has the shortest distance (in the heel) to w_3. 
Further let L_k, L_m be ears such that w_1 is a leaf of L_k and u is a leaf of L_m
and assume {w_1,w'_1}, {u,u'} are edges of L_k, L_m, respectively. 
Then, H', L'_k, L'_m are obtained by deleting the edges {w_1,w'_1}, {u,u'} 
and adding the new edges {w_1,u'}, {u,w'_1}. The other ears do not change, namely L'_i=L_i for all i âˆ‰{k,m}.
Note that (H_0, H'_i, L'_i)^n admits H_0, S.

  * The closure of the pair H, â„‹ is the set of all pairs H',
â„‹', where H' is a trigraph and â„‹' is an ear decomposition of H' admitting H_0, S,
such that H', â„‹' are  obtained from H, â„‹ by a sequence of the following two operations: 
(1) a modification of the current ear decomposition to another one admitting H_0, S,  and (2) a local exchange on the current trigraph.

rubbing out all the edges of G.

Let G be a 5-critical graph, RâŠŠ V(G) with |R|â‰¥ 5 and Ï• a 4-coloring of G[R]. Now let W be a 5-critical subgraph of G_Ï•(R) and X be the graph on the set of vertices x_i. Then we say that R' = (V(W)-V(X))âˆª R is the critical extension of R with extender W. We call Wâˆ© X the core of the extension. 

If in G a vertex in W-V(X) has more neighbors in R than in V(W âˆ© X), or there exists an edge in G[V(W)-V(X)] that is not in W-V(X), or W[X] is not a complete graph, then we say that the extension is incomplete . Otherwise, we say the extension is complete . If R'=V(G), we say the extension is spanning . If the extension is both complete and spanning, then we say it is total .

Let G be a 4-critical graph, RâŠŠ V(G) with |R|â‰¥ 4 and Ï• be a 3-coloring of G[R]. Now let W be a 4-critical subgraph of G_Ï•(R) and T be the triangle corresponding to R in G. Then we say that R' = (W-T)âˆª R is a critical extension of R with extender W. We refer to Wâˆ© T as the core of the extension.

If a vertex in W-T has more neighbors in R then in X or there exists an edge in G[V(W-T)] that is not in W-T, then we say that the extension is incomplete . Otherwise, we say the extension is complete . If R'=V(G), then we say the extension is spanning . A total extension is an extension that is both complete and spanning.

Let G be a 4-critical graph, RâŠŠ V(G) with |R|â‰¥ 4 and Ï• a 3-coloring of G[R]. Now let W be a 4-critical subgraph of G_Ï•(R) and T the triangle corresponding to R in G. Then we say that R' = (V(W)-V(T))âˆª R is the critical extension of R with extender W. We call Wâˆ© T the core of the extension. If in G a vertex in W-V(T) has more neighbors in R than in V(W âˆ© T) or there exists an edge in G[V(W)-V(T)] that is not in W-V(T), then we say that the extension is incomplete . Otherwise, we say the extension is complete . If R'=V(G), we say the extension is spanning . If the extension is both complete and spanning, then we say it is total .

[Properties of empty 4-simplices,Â <cit.>]

 


  * There are infinitely many lattice empty 4-simplices of width 1 (e.g., cones over empty tetrahedra) and of width 2Â <cit.>. 

  * Among the simplices of determinant â‰¤ 1600 there are 178 of width three, one of width four, and none of larger width, and their maximum determinant is 179. The computation up to determinant 1000 was done by Haase and ZieglerÂ <cit.> and the extension up to 1600 by PerrielloÂ <cit.>.

  * The total amount of empty lattice 4-simplices of width greater than 2 is finiteÂ <cit.>. 

  * Every empty 4-simplex is cyclicÂ <cit.>. The same is not true in dimension five.

[Decision tree]
Let F be a function that is not constant zero.
Then a decision tree T for F is defined as follows.
Suppose that Var(F)={x}.
Then the root rt of T is labelled with x. If both {x} and { x} are satisfying
assignments of F then rt has two outgoing edges labelled with x and x, respectively
(the leaves are not labelled with variables).
If the only satisfying assignment of F is {x} then the only outgoing edge of rt is labelled
with x. Finally, if the only satisfying assignment of rt is { x} then the only outgoing edge
is labelled with x.

Now, assume that |Var(F)|>1. Let x âˆˆ Var(F).
Label rt with x. If both x and x occur in satisfying assignments
of F then rt has two outgoing edges labelled with x and x.
Let u_1 and u_2 be the respective heads of these edges.
Then the subtree of T rooted by u_1 is a decision tree for F|_x
and the subtree rooted by u_2 is a decision tree for F|_ x.

If there is exactly one â„“âˆˆ{x, x} in the satisfying assignments of F then
there is only one outgoing edge labelled with â„“
and the subtree rooted by the head of this edge is a decision tree for F|_â„“.

A decision tree D for G consists of a perfect binary tree, i.e., a rooted tree such that all non-leaf nodes have two descendants, and a labeling of each node of the tree by elements of E such that the labels along any particular branch give a permutation of E.

where G_1, â€¦, G_r are indecomposable and for 1 â‰¤ i < j â‰¤ r either V(G_i)âˆ© V(G_j) = âˆ… or V(G_i)âˆ© V(G_j) = { v_ij}, where v_ij is a free vertex of G_i and G_j. The decomposition (<ref>)  is unique up to ordering and we say that G is decomposable into indecomposable graphs G_1, â€¦,G_r.

There are k components in the resulting graph, each of which is an unordered increasing tree, whose root vertex is on the chain from a_1 to a_k. The disjunctive sum G_1+G_2 of two games G_1 and G_2 is defined recursively as the game in which at each step the current player can decide to move in either game, but not both. Formally,

The disjunctive sum between two positions of combinatorial games G and H is the position in which a player can play in one of G and H but not both simultaneously.

  orÂ (<ref>). For example, if an edge e'_i appears

  Ï‰_e'_i is 2. If one of the appearances has a 1 and the other

[The Duality TheoremThe Duality Theorem, <cit.>]  Let p(x,y) be a tropical polynomial with P=Newt(p) two-dimensional.  Then the tropical curve ğ’¯(p) is dual to the subdivision of P induced by the coefficients of p(x,y) in the following sense:



  * Vertices of ğ’¯(p) correspond to polygons in the subdivision of P.

  * Edges of ğ’¯(p) correspond to interior edges in the subdivision of P.

  * Rays of ğ’¯(p) correspond to boundary edges in the subdivision of P.

  * Regions of â„^2 separated by ğ’¯(p) correspond to lattice points of P used in the subdivision.

Moreover, two vertices of ğ’¯(p) are connected by an edge if and only if their corresponding polygons in the subdivision share an edge, and the edge in the Newton polygon is perpendicular to the edge in the subdivision; and the rays emanating from a vertex in ğ’¯(p) correspond to boundary edges of the corresponding polygon in the subdivision, with the rays in the outward perpendicular directions to the boundary edges of P.

	Given p,p'âˆˆğ’«^âˆ˜âˆ™_2,nb and sectors S in p and S' in p', we number the points in (S) and (S') with respect to the cyclic order. We say that (p,S) and (p',S') are equivalent if the following four conditions are met:

  * For all i, the i-th point of S belongs to a block crossing âˆ‚ S in p if and only if the i-th point of S' belongs to a block crossing âˆ‚ S' in p'. 
		
  * For all i,j, the i-th and j-th points of S form a block in p if and only if the i-th and j-th points of S' form a block in p'.
                
                In other words: p restricted to S coincides with p' restricted to S' (up to rotation).

For a skew shifted tableau with entries i_j or i'_j for iâˆˆ{1,2,â€¦} where j is any symbol, we call i the gene family of an entry i_j or i'_j and j the gene . Two such tableaux are equivalent if they are the same up to a relabeling of the genes j.  An equivalence class T of these tableaux is a semistandard genomic tableau if:


  * The tableau T_ss obtained by forgetting the gene subscripts is semistandard and in canonical form.

  * Each gene j consists only of letters i_j and i'_j for some i, and its letters are consecutive in standardization order.

  * For every primed entry i'_j, there is an unprimed letter i_k preceding it in reading order from the same family i but different gene kâ‰  j.

  * No two squares of the same gene are horizontally or vertically adjacent.

The K-theoretic content of T is (c_1, â€¦, c_r) where c_i is the number of genes in the i-th family. Finally, T is ballot if it is semistandard and has the following property:


  (*) Let T' be any genomic tableau obtained by deleting, within each gene family of T, all but one of every gene. Let T'_ss be the tableau obtained by deleting the corresponding entries of T_ss. Then the reading word of T'_ss is ballot for all T' obtained in this way.

Then there exists a constant c > 0 so that all but exponentially few prime alternating knot types K have a minimal alternating diagram which contains at least cn instances of P.   * For every chord in D,Î“,C containing vertices a and b, there is a chord of the same sign in D'_Î“,C of the same sign connecting vertices a and b.

Furthermore, the chords connecting a to b and a to c in D'_Î“,C have the same signs as the edges connecting the triad point of e to b and c in D_Î“,C, respectively.

  * For every triad e in D_Î“,C in which all edges have negative sign, for some labeling a,b,c of the vertices of e, D'_Î“,C contains a chord connecting a Â±Ïµ to b and a chord connecting a âˆ“Ïµ to c, with Â±Ïµ chosen in such a way that the chords are linked. Furthermore, the chords connecting a to b and a to c in D'_Î“,C have signs opposite to the edges connecting the triad point of e to b and c in D_Î“,C, respectively.

  * For every double chord e in D_Î“,C with principal vertex a, for some labeling b, c of the nonprincipal vertices of e, there is a chord in D'_Î“,C connecting a - Ïµ to b and a chord in D'_Î“,C connecting a + Ïµ to c. These chords are not linked.

      There is a colour c and pairwise disjoint
      subsets A_1, A_2, B_1, B_2, C_1, C_2âŠ† V such that
      |D_1âˆª D_2|â‰¥(1-Î·)n and K[D_1,D'_2] is (Î·,c)-complete
      for all D,D'âˆˆ{A,B,C} with Dâ‰  D', the edges in all these

      C_2. Further there are sets A_B A_C=A_2, B_A B_C=B_2, and
      C_A C_B C_C=C_2, each of which is either empty or
      non-negligible, such that the
      following conditions are satisfied for all {D,D',Dâ€}={A,B,C}:
      
        
  *  |A_1|â‰¥|B_1|â‰¥|C_1âˆª C_C| and
          |D_D'|=|D'_D|â‰¤ n-|Dâ€_2|,
        
  *  either C_C=âˆ… or A_B=âˆ…,

        |A_2âˆª B_2âˆª C_Aâˆª C_B|â‰¤(1-Î·)3/2n,

plain_text_def: Given a spread set ğ’®={U_1,â€¦,U_q-1} of nonzero matrices, one forms a (q-1) Ã— (q-1) matrix whose (i,j) entry is 0, +1 or -1 according as (U_i-U_j) is zero, square or nonsquare, respectively. Border this matrix with a leading row and column of 1s (except for the first entry on the diagonal which remains zero) to form a symmetric qÃ— q matrix A with 0 on the diagonal, and Â± 1 in every non-diagonal entry. Finally, form the matrix F = AA^t (with the product being taken in the rational numbers). The fingerprint of the spread set is the multiset of the absolute values of the entries of F.

A segment
  T_a,b is forbidden if, after inferring the positions of
  a and b in rows 2 to

  *  a and b form a descent on row 2 and, if

  *  a and

  In both cases the bars that we reference belong to the segment

Let G be a reduced plabic graph.  We associate a quiver Q(G) as follows.  The vertices of 
Q(G) are labeled by the faces of G.  We say that a vertex of Q(G) is frozen
if the 
corresponding face is incident to the boundary of the disk, and is mutable otherwise.
For each edge e in G which separates two faces, at least one of which is mutable, 
we introduce an arrow connecting the faces;
 this arrow is oriented so that it â€œsees the white endpoint of e to the left and the 
black endpoint to the rightâ€ as it crosses over e.  We then remove oriented 2-cycles
from the resulting quiver, one by one, to get Q(G). See <ref>.

Let G be a graph.  We say two disjoint edges uv and xy form a gap in G if G does not have an edge with one 
endpoint in {u,v} and the other in {x,y}.
A graph without gaps is called gap-free .  Equivalently, G is gap-free if and only if G^c contains no induced C_4.

Let G be a graph.  We say two edges (w, x) and (y, z) form a gap in G if G does not have an edge with one 
endpoint in {w, x} and the other in {y, z}.
A graph without gaps is called gap-free .  Equivalently, G is gap-free if and only if G^c contains no induced C_4.

Two such tableaux are equivalent if they are the same up to a relabeling of the genes j.  An equivalence class T of these tableaux is a semistandard genomic tableau if:


  * The tableau T_ss obtained by forgetting the gene subscripts is semistandard and in canonical form.

  * Each gene j consists only of letters i_j and i'_j for some i, and its letters are consecutive in standardization order.

  * For every primed entry i'_j, there is an unprimed letter i_k preceding it in reading order from the same family i but different gene kâ‰  j.

  * No two squares of the same gene are horizontally or vertically adjacent.

The K-theoretic content of T is (c_1, â€¦, c_r) where c_i is the number of genes in the i-th family. Finally, T is ballot if it is semistandard and has the following property:


  (*) Let T' be any genomic tableau obtained by deleting, within each gene family of T, all but one of every gene. Let T'_ss be the tableau obtained by deleting the corresponding entries of T_ss. Then the reading word of T'_ss is ballot for all T' obtained in this way.

[<cit.>]
Let T be a genomic tableau with entries i_j. We call i the gene family and j the gene . First, we say T is semistandard if:


  * The tableau T_ss obtained by forgetting the genes is semistandard (that is, each gene family forms a horizontal strip);

  * Within each gene family, the genes form a Pieri strip.

We say the K-theoretic content of T is (c_1, â€¦, c_r) if c_i is the max-content of the Pieri strip of genes in the i-th gene family. Finally, we say T is ballot if it is semistandard and has the following property:


  (*) Let T' be any genomic tableau obtained by deleting, within each gene family of T, all but one of every repeated gene. Let T'_ss be the tableau obtained by deleting the corresponding entries of T_ss. Then the reading word of T'_ss is ballot.

We let Î¹Ì…_A:(A,y,x)â†’(A,y,x) be the mapping defined by (ax)^Î¹Ì…_A=ax^-1 and a^Î¹Ì…_A=a, for every aâˆˆ A. In particular, Î¹Ì…_A is an automorphism of (A,y,x).

A Dellac configuration of size n is a tableau of width n and height 2n which contains 2n dots between the lines y=x and y=n+x, such that each row contains exactly one dot and each column contains exactly two dots. We denote by inv(C) the number of inversions of C. Given a graph G, the line graph L(G) is the graph whose vertices are the edges of G, and two vertices x and y in L(G) are connected iff the corresponding edges share a common endpoint in G.

For a graph X = (V(X), E(X)) the line graph L(X) is defined as the graph on the vertex set E(X), for which e_1, e_2âˆˆ E(X) are adjacent in L(X) if and only if they are incident to a common vertex in X.

Let X be a graph. Denote by V(X) and E(X) the set of vertices and the set of edges of X. The line graph of X is the graph L(X) with the set of vertices E(X), in which distinct e_1, e_2âˆˆ E(X) are adjacent if they (as edges of X) share a vertex.

Consider an n-vertex (d+1)-uniform hypergraph H such that every d-tuple of vertices is contained in at most t=O(1) edges,
and apply the following procedure:


  * let X be the subset of vertices obtained by choosing each vertex independently at random with probability p, such that
pn = ( n/(t logloglog n) )^3/(3d-1),

  * remove the minimum number of vertices of X so that the resulting subset Y induces a triangle-free linear[A hypergraph is linear if it has no pair of distinct edges sharing two or more vertices.] hypergraph H[Y].

Then with high probability H[Y] has an independent set of size at least ( n/tlogn/t)^1/d.

Let v be a vertex of a simple graph G. Then the local complement of
G with respect to v is the graph G^v with V(G^v)=V(G) and
E(G^v)={xy| either xâˆ‰ N(v) and xyâˆˆ E(G) or x,yâˆˆ N(v)
and xyâˆ‰ E(G)}.

Let H be a graph and v a looped vertex of H. The local complement of H at v, denoted by H*v, is the graph obtained from H by complementing the subgraph induced by N_H(v).

In other words, for all p âŠ† V(H) = V(H*v) with |p| âˆˆ{1,2}, we have p âˆˆ E(H*v) if and only if either (1) p âˆ‰ E(H) and p âŠ† N_H(v) or (2) p âˆˆ E(H) and p âŠˆN_H(v).

If v is a vertex of a (marked) graph G then the local complement
G^v is obtained from G by toggling every edge incident only on
neighbor(s) of v.

Let G be a graph with a vertex v. Then the local complement G^v
is the looped simple graph obtained from G by toggling the loop status of
every neighbor of v, and toggling the adjacency status of every pair of
neighbors of v.

If G is a graph and vâˆˆ V(G) then the local complement
G^v is the graph obtained from G by toggling edges involving only
neighbors of v. That is, if wâ‰  v is adjacent to v then w is looped
in G^v if and only if it is not looped in G; and if vâ‰  xâ‰  yâ‰ 
v and x, y are both neighbors of v then x, y are adjacent in
G^v if and only if they are not adjacent in G.

If v is a vertex of a simple graph G then the local complement
G^v is the graph obtained from G by reversing the adjacency status of
every pair of neighbors of v. A graph that can be obtained from G through
some sequence of local complementations is locally equivalent to G.
Graphs G and H are locally equivalent if one can be obtained from the other through some sequence of local complementations and loop complementations.
We say that a simplicial complex is locally finite if each vertex is contained in finitely many simplices.

  _(g)(v) is the union of s edges e_1,â€¦, e_s

  for all i such that the resulting complex with multiplicities is
  balanced at v, contains an edge of positive multiplicity and it
  does not agree with _(g)(v) as complexes with
  multiplicities.

[Locally reducible cluster]
A cluster is locally reducible if there exists an L or B-reduction where the active vertices of the reduction are part of the cluster such that the reduced cluster does not contain any adjacent 5-vertices.

A marking of a floor diagram  is defined by the following
four step process

Step 1: 
For each vertex j of  create s_j new indistinguishable vertices and
connect them to j with new edges directed towards j.

Step 2: For each vertex j of  create m+s_j- div(j) new
indistinguishable vertices and connect them to j with new edges
directed away from j. This makes the divergence of vertex j equal
to m.


Step 3: Subdivide each edge of the original floor
diagram  into two
directed edges by introducing a new
vertex for each edge. The new edges inherit their weights and orientations. Denote the
resulting graph .

[Mobility]
	Let d be a dissimilarity map on X and let Î´ be an ultrametric that is closest to d in the â„“^âˆ-norm. Let T be a resolution of the topology of Î´ and let Î± be the internal nodes weighting s.t. d_T,Î±=Î´.   * Î±Ì‚(v) â‰¤Î±(v).
	
	In this case, we say that Î´Ì‚ is obtained from Î´ by sliding v down. If moreover v is no longer mobile in d_T,Î±Ì‚, i.e., if Î±Ì‚(v) = max{Î±(y) :y âˆˆDes_T(v)}, or Î±Ì‚(v) is the minimum value s.t. d_T,Î±Ì‚ is nearest to d in the â„“^âˆ-norm, then we say that Î´Ì‚ is obtained from Î´ by sliding v all the way down.

A mobile is a planar tree â€“ that is, a map with a single face â€“ such that there are two kinds of vertices (black and white), edges only occur as blackâ€“black edges or blackâ€“white edges, and black vertices additionally have so-called â€œlegsâ€ attached to them (which are not considered edges), whose number equals the number of white neighbour vertices. A bipartite mobile is  a mobile without blackâ€“black edges. The degree of a black vertex is the number of half-edges plus the number of legs that are 
attached to it. A mobile is called rooted if an edge is distinguished and oriented.

* A ((2k+1)-orthogonal ) vacillating tableau of length r is a sequence of Young diagrams âˆ…=Î¼^0, Î¼^1,â€¦,Î¼^r=Î¼ each of at most k parts, such that:

  * A ((2k+1)-orthogonal ) highest weight word is a word w with letters in {Â± 1, Â± 2, â€¦, Â± k, 0} of length r such that for every initial segment s of w the following holds (we write #i for the number of i's in s):

The partition (#1-#(-1),#2-#(-2),â€¦, #k - #(-k)) is the weight of a highest weight word. The vacillating tableau corresponding to a word w is the sequence of weights of the initial segments of w.

  * Riordan paths are Motzkin paths without horizontal steps on the x-axis. They consist of up (north-east) steps, down (south-east) steps, and horizontal (east) steps, such that there is no step beneath the x-axis and no horizontal step on the x-axis.

A k-tuple of Riordan paths of length r is a vacillating tableau of length r if it meets the following conditions:


  * The first path is a Riordan path of length r.

  * Path i has steps where path i-1 has horizontal steps. Path i is never higher than path i-1.

For a better readability we sometimes label the steps with 1,â€¦,r in order to see which steps belong together and shift paths together.

The corresponding highest weight word is described as follows: A value i is an up-step in path i and a horizontal step in paths 1 up to i-1. Similarly a value -i is a down-step in path i and a horizontal step in paths 1 up to i-1 and a value 0 is a horizontal step in every path, including k.

By abuse of terminology we refer to all three objects as vacillating tableaux .

We call the partition (#1-#(-1),#2-#(-2),â€¦, #k - #(-k)) the weight of a highest weight word. The vacillating tableau corresponding to a word w is the sequence of weights of the initial segments of w.

A parallelogram polyomino P (see an example in FigureÂ <ref>(a)) is an (edge-)connected set of unit cells in the Cartesian plane,

and which never meet except at their beginning and end.

Let there be n cars C_1,â€¦,C_n
of sizes y_1,â€¦,y_n, 
where y_1, â€¦, y_n are positive integers.
Assume there are z-1 + âˆ‘_i=1^n y_i spaces in a row,
where the trailer occupies the z-1 first spaces.
Furthermore, let car C_i have the preferred spotÂ c_i.
Now let the cars
in the orderÂ C_1 through C_n
park according to the following rule:

Starting at position c_i,
car C_i
looks for the first empty spot j â‰¥ c_i.
If the spacesÂ j through j+y_i-1 are empty, then car C_i
parks in these spots.
If any of the spots
j+1 through j+y_i-1 is already occupied,
then there will be a collision, and the result is not a parking sequence.


Iterate this rule for all the cars
C_1, C_2, â€¦, C_n.
We call (c_1,â€¦, c_n) a parking sequence
for yâƒ—=(y_1,â€¦,y_n)
if all n cars can park without any collisions
and without leaving
the z-1 + âˆ‘_i=1^n y_i parking spaces.

A projective plane is a point-line incidence structure with the following three properties:


  (P1) Every two different points are contained in a unique line.

  (P2) Every two different lines intersect in exactly
one point.

  (P3) There are four points with the property that no three of them are
contained in a single line.

[<cit.>]
  A quasi-key tableau is quasi-Yamanouchi if the leftmost occurrence of each entry i is either
  
  
  * in row i, or
  
  * weakly left of some entry i+1.
  
  Denote the set of quasi-Yamanouchi quasi-key tableaux of shape a by (a).

[<cit.>]
  A Kohnert tableau is quasi-Yamanouchi if each nonempty row i either has an entry equal to i or has a cell weakly left of some cell in row i+1.

A Kohnert tableau is quasi-Yamanouchi if for each nonempty row i, one of the following holds:
  
  
  * there is a cell in row i with entry equal to i, or
  
  * there is a cell in row i+1 that lies weakly right of a cell in row i.
  
  Denote the set of quasi-Yamanouchi Kohnert tableaux of content a by (a).

A lock tableau is quasi-Yamanouchi if for each nonempty row i, one of the following holds:
  
  
  * there is a cell in row i with entry equal to i, or
  
  * there is a cell in row i+1 that lies weakly right of a cell in row i.
  
  Denote the set of quasi-Yamanouchi lock tableaux of content a by (a).

The queer lowering operator , denoted by f_0, acts on semistandard shifted tableaux by: if T has no cell labeled 1 or if T has a cell labeled 2, then f_0(T)=0; otherwise f_0(T) changes the rightmost 1 in the first row of T to 2 if it is on the main diagonal and to 2 otherwise.

A quiverquiver is a directed graph without loops (arrows from a vertex to itself) and without oriented 2-cycles.

A quiver Q is a directed graph.  We will only work with quivers on a finite number of vertices and which contains no loops (1-cycles) or 2-cycles.  However, we do allow our quivers to have multiple edges between a pair of vertices, but since there are no 2-cycles, this means that all edges between two vertices must have the same direction.  In general there is no restriction against oriented cycles on â‰¥ 3 vertices.

We define the following types of directed graphs as subgraphs
  of the final component of the Markov chain.


  * A rooted tree is a weakly connected digraph with one vertex which has out-degree
0, while all other vertices have out-degree 1. The vertex with out-degree 0
is called the root of the tree.

1. Each component of a
functional digraph consists of a directed cycle and some trees rooted at
vertices of the cycle. For a functional digraph D, let ğ’_D be the
set of all cycles of D.

If C is an allowable cycle, we define a shift of C to be the cycle formed by replacing each path in C of the form f_1â€“eâ€“f_2 (where e is an edge of G and f_1 and f_2 are the two incident faces) by one of the two paths of the form f_1â€“xâ€“f_2 or f_1â€“yâ€“f_2 (where x and y are the two endpoints of e), and then replacing each path in C of the form uâ€“fâ€“v where u and v are adjacent in G by the path uâ€“uvâ€“v.

[Shift]

Let AâŠ† be a set of natural numbers. For a number nâˆˆ, the shiftshift of a set A-n is defined as the set A-n := { kâˆˆ : k+nâˆˆ A}, or more suggestively

    kâˆˆ A-n  (k+n) âˆˆ A.

In other words, subtract n from the numbers in the set A and keep the nonnegative results.

Define the shifted code of a strict partition Î» to be the infinite sequence of letters R and U obtained by tracing along the bottom-right edge of the shifted Young diagram of shape Î» in the fourth quadrant together with the positive x-axis, starting at the bottom-right corner of the leftmost box on the bottom row of the diagram.

Define the shifted code of a strict partition Î» to
be the infinite sequence of letters R and U obtained from the
shifted Young diagram of shape Î» as follows.  Consider the
shifted Young diagram top and left aligned in the 4^th
quadrant of the xy-plane together with the positive x-axis.
Starting at the bottom right corner of the leftmost box in the last
row, trace along the rightmost edge of the shifted Young diagram,
then right along the positive x-axis.  Equivalently, start the
code at the lowest place where the line y=-x intersects the
shifted Young diagram.  The shifted code of the strict partition is
the sequence of R's and U's obtained from this path, where R
corresponds to a unit right step and U corresponds to a unit up
step.

  *

  * else if x=i and y does not exist or y > i+1, then f_i changes x to i+1;
      
  * else if x=i, then f_i changes x to i+1 and removes the marking (if any) from northwestern-most cell on the (i+1)-ribbon containing y;

The shifted lowering operators , denoted by f_i, act on semistandard shifted tableaux by: f_i(T)=0 if m_i(w(T)) â©½ 0; otherwise, letting p be the smallest index such that m_i(w(T),p) = m_i(w(T)), letting x denote the entry of T corresponding to w_p, and letting y be the entry north of x and z the entry east of x, we have

Let G be a graph with distinct vertices a and b. The shortest path graph of G with respect to a and b is the graph S(G,a,b) in which every vertex U corresponds to a shortest path in G between a and b, and two vertices U,W âˆˆ V(S(G,a,b)) are adjacent if and only if their corresponding paths in G differ in exactly one vertex.

Let G be a graph with distinct vertices a and b. The shortest path graph (SPG) of G with respect to a and b, denoted S(G,a,b), is a graph where each vertex corresponds to a shortest path in G from a to b, and two vertices U,W âˆˆ V(S(G,a,b)) are adjacent if and only if their corresponding paths in G differ in exactly one vertex.

A trivalent diagram is a connected, two colored bipartite graph (parallel edges allowed but not loops) such that every black vertex is of degree 1 or 3 and every white vertex is of degree 1 or 2, with a cyclic order imposed on the edges incident to each vertex. A EW-tableau T is a 0/1-filling of a Ferrers diagram with the following properties:

The size of a EW-tableau is its semiperimeter less one, that is, one less than the sum of its numbers of rows and columns. Let (F) be the set of EW-tableaux on the diagram F.

located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere above a,
and the row containing a and b is strictly longer than the row containing c
and T(a) â‰¥ T(c) â‰¥ T(b).
