A skew diagram Î¸ is a strip if Î¸ is edgewise connected and it contains no 2Ã— 2 blocks of boxes.

A strip in a planar quad-graph Î› is a path on its dual  such that two successive faces share an edge and the strip leaves a face in the opposite edge where it enters it. Moreover, strips are assumed to have maximal length, i.e., there are no strips containing it apart from itself.

A strong placement game is a combinatorial game which satisfies the following:


  (i) The starting position is the empty board.

  (ii) Players place pieces on empty spaces of the board according to the rules.

  (iii) Pieces are not moved or removed once placed.

  (iv) The rules are such that if it is possible to reach a position through a sequence of legal moves, then any sequence of moves leading to this position consists only of legal moves.

The Trivial placement game on a board is the strong placement game that has no additional rules.

A strong placement game is a combinatorial game played on a graph which satisfies the following:


  (i) The starting position is the empty board.

  (ii) Players place pieces on empty spaces of the board according to the rules.

  (iii) Pieces are not moved or removed once placed.

  (iv) The rules are such that if it is possible to reach a position through a sequence of legal moves, then any sequence of moves leading to this position consists only of legal moves.

The Trivial placement game on a board is the placement game that has no additional rules.

Given a chord diagram D, surgery of D is the following process: For each chord e connecting points a,b, delete a neighborhood of e and connect the obtained endpoints a+Ïµ to b-Ïµ and a-Ïµ to b+Ïµ if e is positive, and a+Ïµ to b+Ïµ and a-Ïµ to b-Ïµ if e is negative. This produces a family of circles; these are called the result of surgery of D.

The wedge (product) of K_1 and K_2, (K_1,v_1)âˆ¨ (K_2,v_2), is a simplicial complex obtained by identifying v_1 and v_2. The homotopy type of the resulting simplicial complex is preserved under change of the base points v_1 and v_2 inside the connected components in the original complexes. The thread decomposition of Tâˆˆ(a) partitions cells into threads as follows. Beginning with the rightmost column, select the lowest available cell to begin the thread. After threading a cell in column j+1, thread the lowest available cell in column j that is weakly above the threaded cell in column j+1. Continue the thread until all columns are threaded or no possible choice remains. Continue threading until all cells are part of some thread.

[<cit.>]
  The thread decomposition of a generic Kohnert diagram partitions the cells into threads as follows. Beginning with the rightmost column, select the lowest available cell to begin the thread. After threading a cell in column j+1, thread the lowest available cell in column j that is weakly above the threaded cell in column j+1. Continue the thread until all columns are threaded or no choices remain. Continue threading until all cells are part of some thread.
A graph is called threshold graph if it does not contain C_4, P_4 or 2K_2 as its induced subgraph.

[Threshold graph]
A graph G = (V,E) is a threshold graph if it can be constructed
from the empty graph by repeatedly adding either an isolated node or a dominating node.
A graph G is a threshold graph if it can be constructed recursively from K_1 by successively adding either a dominating vertex or an isolated vertex.

[Tree Decomposition, Treewidth]
	A tree decomposition of a graph G = (V, E) is a pair (T, X) of a
	tree T = (N, F) and an indexed family of vertex sets (X_t)_t âˆˆ N
	(called bags ), such that the following properties hold.
	
	  
  * Each vertex v âˆˆ V is contained in at least one bag.
	  
  * For each edge e âˆˆ E there exists a bag containing both endpoints.
	  
  * For each vertex v âˆˆ V, the bags in the tree decomposition that
	  contain v form a subtree of T.
	
	The width of a tree decomposition is the size of the largest bag minus 1
	and the treewidth of a graph is the minimum width of all its tree
	decompositions.

Given a plabic graph G,
the trip T_i is the directed path which starts at the boundary vertex
i, and follows the â€œrules of the road": it turns right at a
black vertex and   left at a white vertex.
Note that T_i  will also
end at a boundary vertex.  The decorated trip permutation Ï€_G
is the permutation such that Ï€_G(i)=j whenever T_i
ends at j.  Moreover, if there is a white (respectively, black)
boundary leaf at boundary vertex i, then Ï€_G(i)=i is a 
counterclockwise (respectively, clockwise) fixed point.

Let G be a reduced plabic graph as above
with boundary vertices b_1,â€¦, b_n.  
The trip from b_i is the path 
obtained by starting from b_i and traveling along 
edges of G according to the rule that each time we reach an internal white vertex we turn 
right, and each time we reach an internal black vertex we turn left. 
This trip ends at some boundary vertex b_Ï€(i).  
If the starting and ending points of the trip are the same vertex b_j, 
we set the color of the fixed point Ï€(j)=j to match the orientation of the trip
(clockwise or counterclockwise.)



In this way we associate a decorated permutation 
Ï€_G=(Ï€(1),â€¦,Ï€(n)) to each reduced plabic graph G, which 
is called the 
decorated trip permutation of G.

Given a reduced plabic graph G,
a  trip T is a directed path which starts at
some boundary vertex
i, and follows the â€œrules of the road": it turns (maximally) right at a
black vertex,  and (maximally) left at a white vertex.
 Note that T will also
end at a boundary vertex j; we then refer to this trip as
T_i â†’ j. Setting Ï€(i)=j for each such trip,
 we associate a (decorated) trip permutation
Ï€_G=(Ï€(1),â€¦,Ï€(n)) to each reduced plabic graph G, where a fixed point Ï€(i)=i is colored white (black) if there is a white (black) lollipop at boundary vertex i.

Let G be a reduced plabic graph 
with boundary vertices 1,â€¦, n.
The trip T_i from i is the path
obtained by starting from i and traveling along
edges of G according to the rule that each time we reach an internal black vertex we turn
(maximally) right, and each time we reach an internal white vertex we turn (maximally) left.
This trip ends at some boundary vertex Ï€(i).
In this way we associate a trip permutation
Ï€_G=(Ï€(1),â€¦,Ï€(n)) to each reduced plabic graph G,
and we say that G has type Ï€_G .
	(Because one can reverse each trip, it is clear that Ï€_G is a permutation.)

Let G be a connected graph. A tube of G is a subset B âŠ‚ V(G) which generates a connected subgraph of G. A tube B is trivial if |B| = 1.

A tube is a set of nodes of  whose induced graph is a connected subgraph of .
For a given tube t and a graph , let _t denote the induced subgraph on the graph . When  is connected, the set of all nodes of  determines the universal tube t_.

For any tube tâˆˆ, the reconnected complement _t^* is the graph whose set of nodes is ()âˆ–{t}, and whose edges are determined by the pairs of nodes {v,w } satisfying one of the following conditions:

  * the edge { v,w} belongs to (),

Let G be a finite connected simple graph.  A tube is a set
of nodes of G whose induced graph is a connected subgraph of G.
For a given tube t and a graph G, let G(t) denote the induced
subgraph on the graph G. We will often refer to the induced graph
itself as the tube. Two tubes u and v may interact on the graph
as follows:


  * Tubes are nested if  u âŠ‚ v.

  * Tubes are far apart if u âˆª v is not a tube in G, that is, the induced subgraph of the union
 is not connected, (equivalently
none of the nodes of u are adjacent to a node of v).

Tubes are compatible if they are either nested or far apart. We call G
itself the universal tube .
 A tubing U of G is a set of tubes of G such that every pair of tubes in U is
 compatible; moreover, we force every tubing of G to contain (by default) its universal tube.
By the
 term k-tubing we refer to a tubing made up of k tubes, for k âˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}.

Let G be a finite connected simple graph, with n numbered nodes.
A tube is a set of nodes of G whose induced graph is a
connected subgraph of G. Two tubes u and v may interact on the
graph as follows:


  * Tubes are nested if  u âŠ‚ v.

  * Tubes are far apart if u âˆª v is not a tube in G, that is, the induced subgraph of the union
 is not connected, or
none of the nodes of u are adjacent to a node of v.

Tubes are compatible if they are either nested or far apart.
We call G itself the universal tube .
 A tubing T of G is a set of tubes of G such that every pair of tubes in T is
 compatible; moreover, we force every tubing of G to contain (by default) its universal tube.
By the
 term k-tubing we refer to a tubing made up of k tubes, for k âˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}.

[Limit objects]
Given a sequence (x_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜, we define their ultralimit lim_â†’Î± x_ to be the equivalence class of all sequences (y_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜ such that x_ = y_ for  sufficiently close to Î±.  Note that the ultralimit lim_â†’Î± x_ can also be defined even if x_ is only defined for  sufficiently close to Î±.

An ultralimit of standard natural numbers is known as a limit natural number , an ultralimit of standard real numbers is known as a limit real number , etc.

For any standard object x, we identify x with its own ultralimit lim_â†’Î± x.  Thus, every standard natural number is a limit natural number, etc.

Any operation or relation on standard objects can be extended to limit objects in the obvious manner.  For instance, the sum of two limit real numbers lim_â†’Î± x_, lim_â†’Î± y_ is the limit real number

    lim_â†’Î± x_ + lim_â†’Î± y_ = lim_â†’Î± x_ + y_,

and the statement lim_â†’Î± x_ < lim_â†’Î± y_ means that x_ < y_ for all  sufficiently close to Î±.

[Limit objects]
Given a sequence (x_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜, we define their ultralimit lim_â†’ p x_ to be the equivalence class of all sequences (y_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜ such that x_ = y_ for  sufficiently close to p.  Note that the ultralimit lim_â†’ p x_ can also be defined even if x_ is only defined for  sufficiently close to p.

An ultralimit of standard natural numbers is known as a limit natural number , an ultralimit of standard real numbers is known as a limit real number , etc.

For any standard object x, we identify x with its own ultralimit lim_â†’ p x.  Thus, every standard natural number is a limit natural number, etc.

Any operation or relation on standard objects can be extended to limit objects in the obvious manner.  For instance, the sum of two limit real numbers lim_â†’ p x_, lim_â†’ p y_ is the limit real number

    lim_â†’ p x_ + lim_â†’ p y_ = lim_â†’ p x_ + y_,

and the statement lim_â†’ p x_ < lim_â†’ p y_ means that x_ < y_ for all  sufficiently close to p.

[Nonstandard objects]
Given a sequence (x_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜, we define their ultralimit lim_â†’Î± x_ to be the equivalence class of all sequences (y_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜ such that x_ = y_ for  sufficiently close to Î±.  Note that the ultralimit lim_â†’Î± x_ can also be defined even if x_ is only defined for  sufficiently close to Î±.

An ultralimit of standard natural numbers is known as a nonstandard natural number , an ultralimit of standard real numbers is known as a nonstandard real number , and so on.

For any standard object x, we identify x with its own ultralimit lim_â†’Î± x.  Thus, every standard natural number is a nonstandard natural number, etc.

Any operation or relation on standard objects can be extended to nonstandard objects in the obvious manner.  Indeed, if O is a k-ary operation, we define

    O( lim_â†’Î± x^1_, â€¦, lim_â†’Î± x^k_ ) := lim_â†’Î± O( x^1_, â€¦, x^k_ )

and if R is a k-ary relation, we define R(lim_â†’Î± x^1_, â€¦, lim_â†’Î± x^k_ ) to be true iff R(x^1_,â€¦,x^k_) is true for all  sufficiently close to Î±.  One easily verifies that these nonstandard extensions of O and R are well-defined.

[Nonstandard objects and functions]
Given a sequence (x_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜, we define their ultralimit lim_â†’Î± x_ to be the equivalence class of all sequences (y_)_âˆˆ of standard objects in ğ”˜ such that x_ = y_ for  sufficiently close to Î±.  Note that the ultralimit lim_â†’Î± x_ can also be defined even if x_ is only defined for  sufficiently close to Î±.

An ultralimit of standard natural numbers is known as a nonstandard natural number , an ultralimit of standard real numbers is known as a nonstandard real number , and so on.

For any standard object x, we identify x with its own ultralimit lim_â†’Î± x.  Thus, every standard natural number is a nonstandard natural number, etc.

Any operation or relation on standard objects can be extended to nonstandard objects in the obvious manner.  Indeed, if O is a k-ary operation, we define

    O( lim_â†’Î± x^1_, â€¦, lim_â†’Î± x^k_ ) := lim_â†’Î± O( x^1_, â€¦, x^k_ )

and if R is a k-ary relation, we define R(lim_â†’Î± x^1_, â€¦, lim_â†’Î± x^k_ ) to be true iff R(x^1_,â€¦,x^k_) is true for all  sufficiently close to Î±.  One easily verifies that these nonstandard extensions of O and R are well-defined.

[Characterization of the Maximum Independent

  For all positive d we have:

  *  Let S be an MIS of B(d,3). Then the

    stabilizer ofÂ S is a power ofÂ 2.
  
  *  Let b_d,k be the number of orbits of

Given a graph G(V,E) with its vertices colored with black and
white. Any black vertex v can be pressed, which has the following
effect: (a) all neighbors of v change color, white neighbors become
black and vice versa , (b) all pair of neighbors of v change
connectivity, connected pairs become unconnected, unconnected ones
become connected, (c) and finally, v becomes a separated white
vertex. The aim of the game is to transform G into an all white,
empty graph.
